DISTRIBUTIONS

Probability was a proportion (since all outcomes were equally likely)

Relationships between events:
- $A \subset B$: if $A$ occurs, so does $B$ ($A \subset B \land B \subset A \iff A = B$)
- $A \cup B$: at least one of $A$ and $B$ occurs
- $A \cap B$: both $A$ and $B$ occur
- $A^C$: $A$ does note occur
- $A \cap B = \emptyset$: mutually exclusive (do not occur simultaneously)
- $A_1 \dots A_n$ parition $A$: $\forall i \neq j : A_i \cap A_j = \emptyset \land \bigcup A_i = A$
Could also use Venn diagrams (as in set theory)

Definition of probability
One way (not general)!
View $\Pr(\cdot)$ as a function that maps an event to a number in $[0,1]$ and satisfies:
- $\forall A \subseteq \Omega : 0 \le \Pr(A) \le 1$;
- $\Pr(\Omega) = 1$; ($\Pr(\emptyset) = 0$);
- if $A_1 \dots A_n$ parition $A$, $\Pr(A) = \sum{\Pr(A_i)}$ (finite additivity)

Then the the probability function is a distribution (of the unit mass $1$) over events in $\Omega$

Later, extend to countable additivity ($\Omega$ not finite). For a countable partition $A = \bigcup^\infty A_i$, we have $\Pr(A) = \sum^\infty \Pr(A_i)$

General Addition Rules
- $\Pr(A \cup B) = \Pr(A) + \Pr(B) - \Pr(A \cap B)$
- $\Pr(A) + \Pr(A^c) = \Pr(A \cup A^c) = \Pr(\Omega) = 1$

EXAMPLES

EX 1
$60\%$ UNC faculty use Wndows PC, $35\%$ Mac, $30\%$ both. Verify:
- $65\%$ use at least one of the two
- $35\%$ use neither
- $70\%$ do not use both
- $35\%$ use only one of two
Easy w/ Venn diagram or the formulas

EX 2
3 Children: $E_i = \{$ the $i$-th child is a female $\}$ for $i \in [1,3]$
Suppose \begin{align}
\Pr(E_1) &= 0.5, \\
\Pr(E_2) &= 0.51, \\
\Pr(E_3) &= 0.52, \\
\Pr(E_1 \cap E_2) = \Pr(E_1 \cap E_3) &= 0.25, \\
\Pr(E_2 \cap E_3) &= 0.26, \\
\Pr(E_1 \cap E_2 \cap E_3) &= 0.13
\end{align}
- Let $A = \{$at least one is $F\}$, $B=\{$all 3 are $M\}$, $C=\{$exactly 2 are $F\}$
- Calculate the probabilities of the 3 sets above
$\Pr(A) = \Pr(E_1 \cup E_2 \cup E_2) = \Pr(E_1) + \Pr(E_2) + \Pr(E_3) - \Pr(E_1 \cap E_2) - \Pr(E_1 \cap E_3) - \Pr(E_2 \cap E_3) + \Pr(E_1 \cap E_2 \cap E_3) = 0.9$
$\Pr(B) = 1 - \Pr(A) = 0.1$
$\Pr(C) = \Pr(E_1 \cap E_2) + \Pr(E_1 \cap E_3) + \Pr(E_2 \cap E_3) - 3\cdot\Pr(\bigcap E_i) = 0.37$
